2. The Taming of the Shrew (1593) - This classic play is based on Shakespeare's own comedy "The Two Gentlemen of Verona". The story follows the lives of two gentlemen who are both well educated and well traveled, but who have never met each other before they come to a small village in Italy where they happen to be staying at the same hotel. As these two gentlemen spend more time together than they had spent with each other separately before they came to this small village, they begin to develop feelings for each other that are far stronger than any of the feelings that either of these two gentlemen had ever previously developed for each other. conversation.text:
I would recommend "The Secret" and "The Trouble with Harry". Both of these movies are based on the works of Luo Guanzhong, one of China's most famous writers.
"The Secret" is a psychological thriller that revolves around a mysterious stranger who enters into and forever alters the life of a couple. He claims to be pursued by certain authorities who intend to prevent him from disclosing a secret that only he holds, whence the title. Is he lying, or insane - or is he telling the truth? Who, if anyone, is after him? And what *is*  - the secret?
"The Trouble with Harry" is another psychological thriller that revolves around a husband and wife team who play detective, but not in the traditional sense. Instead, the happy duo helps others solve their existential issues, the kind that keep you up at night, wondering what it all means.
The epic hints at what it might mean to travel to wage war, to then try to return to the point of departure, and to have both left behind and carried home chaos.
Overall, "The Secret" and "The Trouble with Harry" are two excellent psychological thrillers based on the works of Luo Guanzhong.
